text: The Enipeas () or Enipeus () is a river in central Greece, tributary of the Pineios near Farkadona. It is long.Greece in Figures January - March 2018, p. 12 Its source is in the northern part of Phthiotis, on the plateau of Domokos. Its course runs through several of the tetrades of ancient Thessaly, from Achaea Phthiotis in South through Phthia to finally flow into the Pineios in Histiaeotis. The banks of the Enipeas constituted the scene of several important battles of history, including those of Cynoscephalae (364 BCE and 197 BCE) and Pharsalus (48 BCE). ==Named after== Enipeus Vallis, a north-south valley on planet Mars is named for this river (and valley), located in the mid-south of the Arcadia quadrangle. ==References== Category:Rivers of Greece Category:Landforms of Phthiotis Category:Rivers of Central Greece Category:Landforms of Larissa (regional unit) Category:Rivers of Thessaly Category:Landforms of Karditsa (regional unit) Category:Landforms of Trikala (regional unit) Category:Geography of ancient Thessaly
